awd_titl_txt: High Order Schemes for Hyperbolic and Convection-dominated Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the PI will perform research in the algorithm design and analysis of high order numerical methods.  These algorithms are used to solve scientific and engineering problems arising from diverse application fields such as aerospace engineering, semi-conductor device design, astrophysics, and biological problems.  Even with today's fast computers, it is still essential to design efficient and reliable algorithms which can be used to obtain accurate solutions to these application problems.  The broader impacts resulting from the proposed activity will be a suite of powerful computational tools, suitable for various applications mentioned above.  These tools are expected to make positive contributions to computer simulations of the complicated solution structure in these applications. 

The algorithms to be investigated include the finite difference and finite volume weighted  essentially non-oscillatory (WENO) schemes and discontinuous Galerkin finite element methods, for  solving hyperbolic and other convection dominated partial differential equations (PDEs). While the emphasis of this project is on algorithm design and analysis, close attention will be paid to applications. Topics of proposed investigations will include the study on high order accurate bound-preserving  algorithms and applications, an inverse Lax-Wendroff procedure for high order numerical boundary  conditions for finite difference schemes on rectangular meshes when the physical boundary is not  aligned with the meshes, WENO schemes with subcell resolution for nonconservative problems,  Lagrangian type finite volume schemes for multi-material flows, energy-conserving discontinuous  Galerkin methods for long time simulation of wave problems, efficient discontinuous Galerkin methods  for front propagation problems with obstacles, superconvergence analysis of discontinuous Galerkin  methods and its applications in adaptive computation, simple WENO limiters for discontinuous Galerkin  methods in unstructured meshes for problems with strong shocks, multi-scale methods based on the  discontinuous Galerkin framework, analysis and numerical solutions for traffic and pedestrian flow  models, turbulence simulation in cosmology, and study on aggregation and coordinated movement in  computational biology.  Problems in applications will motivate the design of new algorithms or new  features in existing algorithms; mathematics tools are used to analyze these algorithms to give  guidelines for their applicability and limitations; practical considerations including parallel  implementation issues are addressed to make the algorithms competitive in large scale calculations; and  collaborations with engineers and other applied scientists enable the efficient application of these new  algorithms or new features in existing algorithms.

por.por_cntn:
We have performed research on the design, analysis, improvement and application of high order accurate nonlinearly stable algorithms for solving hyperbolic conservation laws and convection-diffusion equations, including weighted essentially non-oscillatory (WENO) schemes, discontinuous Galerkin (DG) finite element methods, and other high order methods.  The emphasis of this research is on improving the stability, robustness and applicability of these algorithms to facilitate efficient applications of them in applications including computational fluid dynamics, computational cosmology, computational electro-magnetism, and computational biology.

We have been obtained significant results in the following topics:

(1) We have proved superconvergence results for DG methods applied to linear hyperbolic equations including those with degenerate coefficients, and nonlinear hyperbolic equations.  These results reveal the hidden high order information (higher than expected) of the DG methods, which, among others, could provide guidance in designing adaptive methods for efficient computation.

(2) We have developed and analyzed stability and error estimates for the DG methods coupled with high order implicit-explicit (IMEX) Runge-Kutta and multi-step time discretizations.  The IMEX methods treat the leading derivative terms, which are often linear, implicitly and treat other lower derivative terms, which could be nonlinear, explicitly, thus improving the efficiency of the algorithm.  We have proved rigorously the stability of these methods, under very mild constraints on the time step, upper bounded only by a constant which depends on the coefficient of the leading derivative terms, even though all other lower derivative terms are treated explicitly, for second order convection-diffusion equations, fourth order bi-harmonic type equations, incompressible Navier-Stokes equations, and drift-diffusion and high energy models in semi-conductor device simulations. 

(3) We have developed the inverse Lax-Wendroff (ILW) procedure and the simplified ILW (SILW) procedure for general convection-diffusion equations including compressible Navier-Stokes equations in treating numerical boundary conditions.  The ILW and SILW methods allow us to compute problems in complex geometry with rectangular cartesian meshes, for which the physical boundary is not aligned with the computational grids.  The procedure can be easily implemented, and we have performed mathematical analysis to ensure stability while using the simplest SILW procedure.

(4) We have performed research on bound-preserving high order DG methods for solving problems in physical and engineering applications, including the ideal special relativistic hydrodynamics (RHD), Lagrangian schemes for multi-material compressible flows, and simulation of both steady and unsteady radiative transfer equations in one- and two-dimensional geometry .  These schemes are robust in the simulation of extremely high speed flows or flows near vacuum, for which many high order schemes could generate negative density or pressure leading to blow-ups of the codes.

(5) We have developed and analyzed a new multiscale discontinuous Galerkin (DG) method for stationary Schr\"{o}dinger equations with open boundary conditions which have highly oscillating solutions.  We prove that the DG approximation converges optimally with respect to the mesh size $h$ in $L^2$ norm  without the typical constraint that $h$ has to be smaller than the wave length.  Such multiscale DG methods are very efficient in the simulation in quantum physics.

(6) We have designed a stable, conservative and high order accurate algorithm for solving one and two dimensional hyperbolic conservation laws on arbitrarily distributed point clouds.  The initial condition is given on such a point cloud, and the algorithm can solve for accurate point values of the solution at later time also on this point cloud.  This algorithm has a good potential in many applications.

(7) We have developed and analyzed a non-dissipative discontinuous Galerkin (DG) method for solving the Maxwell's equations in Drude metamaterials.  Non-dissipative schemes have an advantage in long time simulations, and our DG scheme has a particularly simple numerical flux choice.  Both stability and optimal error estimates are proved for this DG scheme.

(8) We have developed and analyzed the Runge-Kutta discontinuous Galerkin (RKDG) method to solve weakly coupled hyperbolic multi-domain problems.  Such problems involve transfer type boundary conditions with discontinuous fluxes between different domains, calling for special techniques to prove stability of the RKDG methods.  We prove both stability and error estimates for our RKDG methods on simple models, and then apply them to a biological cell proliferation model.

(9) We have developed a unified framework for designing high order DG methods which will satisfy entropy inequalities for any given single convex entropy, through suitable numerical quadrature which is specific to this given entropy.  Our framework applies from one-dimensional scalar cases all the way to multi-dimensional systems of conservation laws.  Entropy stable DG methods are more robust in simulating physically relevant solution in computational fluid dynamics and computational magneto-hydrodynamics.

55 refereed journal papers have been published or are accepted for publication which cited partial support by this NSF grant.  The grant supported one Ph.D. student, and helped other students and postdocs of the PI through group discussions.
